title: 107_hr342
content: The Act titled "Make College Affordable Act of 2001" allows for a deduction for higher education expenses under Section 221 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a deduction for qualified higher education expenses and interest on education loans paid by an individual during the taxable year. Limitations include a maximum of $10,000 per student and $20,000 per taxpayer for the deduction. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses and interest on education loans is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The reduction amount is calculated based on a ratio of the taxpayer's income over a certain threshold. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' refers to the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year, excluding specific sections and after applying certain adjustments. Inflation adjustments are made for certain amounts after 2002. The tax deduction for qualified higher education expenses shall be increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year, rounded to the nearest multiple of $5,000. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' includes tuition and fees required for enrollment of the taxpayer, spouse, dependents, or grandchildren at an educational institution. As an eligible student at a higher education institution, room and board expenses are covered while attending. Qualified higher education expenses must be for courses that count towards a degree or certificate. Nonacademic fees like student activity fees are not included. The eligible student's expenses at a higher education institution do not include student activity fees, athletic fees, insurance expenses, or other non-academic expenses. An eligible student is defined as someone who meets certain requirements and is carrying at least half of the normal full-time workload for their course of study. No deduction is allowed without proper identification. The taxpayer must provide the name, age, and taxpayer identification number of the eligible student on their tax return to claim a deduction for higher education expenses. An institution of higher education is defined as one eligible for programs under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term 'qualified higher education loan' refers to a loan made, insured, or guaranteed by the Federal Government, a State, a political subdivision, or an institution of higher education. The amount of interest on such a loan that can be considered for deduction is limited. The term 'qualified higher education expenses' for deduction purposes excludes certain subsections. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for deduction under other tax provisions unless the taxpayer waives the right to the deduction. For a taxable year, a deduction can be claimed for qualified higher education expenses if the taxpayer elects to apply section 25A. No deduction is allowed if another taxpayer can claim a deduction for the same individual. The deduction is limited to expenses exceeding the amount excludable under other provisions. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding the exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. The deduction is allowed only for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year, with certain prepayments allowed for expenses in connection with an academic term beginning in the next taxable year. The deduction is allowed only for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year, with certain prepayments allowed for expenses in connection with an academic term beginning in the next taxable year. The amount of qualified higher education expenses is reduced by certain scholarships and veterans benefits received by the individual for the taxable year. The deduction for qualified higher education expenses is limited to the amount exceeding the exclusion under section 135 or 530(d)(2) for the taxable year. It is allowed for expenses related to enrollment at an institution of higher education during the taxable year, with prepayments allowed for expenses in connection with an academic term beginning in the next taxable year. Married individuals filing separate returns are not eligible for this deduction. Nonresident aliens can only claim this deduction if they are treated as resident aliens of the United States by making a specific election. The Secretary may prescribe regulations regarding this deduction. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for section 6013, including recordkeeping and information reporting. The deduction for higher education expenses under section 221 is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Conforming amendments are made to the table of sections. Section 221 of the Code is amended to include qualified higher education loan terms. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2000.
